stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 'Mole Hideout' area of the cowboy level. He programmed the physics for the Monty Moles' rock-throwing attack and designed a mini-boss encounter with multiple moles. He also showcased a completely new, more stable collision system he had built off-stream.

development_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he wrote a completely new, more stable collision system for the game from scratch because he found the original SM64 implementation to be 'unusable'.
development_findings.quote: I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now. And it's so much more stable.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy is to preserve intentional, high-skill bugs like the Backwards Long Jump (BLJ) while removing glitches that can occur accidentally and disrupt normal gameplay.
development_findings.quote: If there's a bug in Mario 64 that you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I'll leave it in the game. But if it can happen on accident, I'll remove it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze designed and implemented a mini-boss fight for the Mole Hideout, settling on an encounter with five Monty Moles that emerge from random holes after brainstorming ideas live on stream.
Kaze estimates the project is about 80% complete, with three main courses, two side levels, and a Bowser level remaining to be built.
development_findings.quote: We're like 80% of the way there.

development_findings.summary: After failing to get a correct physics formula from ChatGPT, Kaze derived the math for the moles' rock-throwing trajectory himself on stream.
The new, more stable collision system has unintentionally made the Backwards Long Jump glitch more difficult to perform, which Kaze views as a negative side effect.
development_findings.quote: The new collision system made the BLJ more difficult, which Kaze considers a 'bad thing' and would ideally like to see preserved.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes true freedom comes in adulthood with financial independence, contrasting with his dislike for the lack of freedom in high school. He theorizes people like high school because it forces social interactions that build friendships.
context_findings.quote: If you want freedom you need like a job and money and stuff and then you can be free and you just don't get that in school.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a specific philosophy for interpreting feedback, which he calls the 'critic's dilemma.' He focuses on the underlying emotion or problem a player is experiencing, rather than their specific proposed solution, believing that frequent critics can become worse at identifying what makes a game feel good.
context_findings.quote: I don't really think about what they're saying as much as I think about what they were feeling and seeing if I can address their feeling instead of their actual critique.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recounted a sponsorship deal with a company selling a bootleg handheld device. They were angry with his unconventional ad, but he was unconcerned about legal threats due to the nature of their business.
context_findings.quote: The company that's like bootleg devices with 2,000 Nintendo games burned on is gonna sue me, yeah right.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to develop his own original 3D platformer after completing the current project. He intends to launch a Kickstarter and hire other ROM hackers to work with him on it.
context_findings.quote: I'm planning alongside the release of Return to Yoshi's Island I'll probably launch like a Kickstarter for my own game and then transition to working on that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is on a diet and workout plan, expressing satisfaction and pride in his physical transformation.
context_findings.quote: I'm still improving. I think around 40 days into my cut right now. I lost around 15 pounds and dude, I'm starting to look fucking chiseled.

zeina.summary: Zeina has 'banned' Kaze from shaving his head, illustrating a personal dynamic that influences his appearance. She was not home during the stream.
zeina.quote: If it wasn't for my wife banning me from going bald I would have already shaved bald.

key_stories.title: Replacing SM64's 'Unusable' Collision System
key_stories.summary: Frustrated with the instability of the original SM64 collision, Kaze took on the massive task of building a completely new system. He demonstrated its superior stability on stream, showcasing a significant technical improvement for the project.
key_stories.challenge: The original Super Mario 64 collision system was unstable, causing players to get stuck in complex geometry.
key_stories.process: Kaze made the decision off-stream to completely discard the original game's collision code and write a new system to improve the game's core feel and stability.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze built a new, more robust collision system from the ground up. This fixed the stability issues but had the unintended side effect of making the famous 'BLJ' glitch much harder to execute, which Kaze considers a downside.
key_stories.key_quote: I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now. And it's so much more stable.

key_stories.title: Designing the Mole Hideout Boss Fight
key_stories.summary: Having built a boss arena without a boss, Kaze workshopped the encounter live. After weighing different options, he opted for a simple but fitting mini-boss fight with multiple moles, turning a design gap into a practical gameplay test.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to design a boss fight for a circular arena he had already built in the Mole Hideout, but he had no concrete ideas.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed ideas live on stream with his chat. He considered and rejected concepts like a survival mode or overly complex mechanics before settling on a straightforward Whac-A-Mole style encounter that fit the theme and gameplay progression.
key_stories.outcome: He decided on a 'simple fight without a real boss': an encounter where five moles pop out of random holes. This design serves as a final test of the mole-dodging mechanic introduced earlier in the level.
key_stories.key_quote: I kind of made this area before even thinking about it... I think we may need a better idea for the boss fight.

key_stories.title: Solving the Rock Throw Physics
key_stories.summary: When a modern tool like ChatGPT failed to provide the correct physics formula for a projectile, Kaze reverted to fundamentals. He solved the complex physics problem himself on stream, demonstrating his deep technical understanding of the game engine.
key_stories.challenge: To make Monty Moles throw rocks accurately at Mario, Kaze needed to calculate the correct projectile trajectory given N64's gravity.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to use ChatGPT to generate the C code for the physics calculation, but the AI provided a flawed solution. He then abandoned the tool and worked through the physics problem himself, calculating the sum of velocities over time to find the required initial velocity.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully derived the correct formula from first principles, live on stream. He implemented it and got the moles to accurately target and throw rocks at Mario's position.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at this shit. Do you really want me to do this on stream? I don't want to do this on stream... let's just make up bullshit until it works then I guess fuck it.

open_questions.context: Kaze revealed he completely replaced the original SM64 collision system, calling it 'unusable.' This is a fundamental change to the game engine.
questions: What was the final straw that made you decide to replace the entire collision system instead of continuing to patch it?
Can you walk us through the process of designing and building it? How long did that take?
You see the removal of the BLJ as a negative side effect. Are you actively trying to re-implement that bug into your new system, and if so, how do you approach 'designing' a bug?

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to launch a Kickstarter for his own original 3D platformer after this project is finished, aiming for a 'late N64/early GameCube' aesthetic.
questions: You plan to hire other ROM hackers for your original game. What skills from the hacking scene do you believe are most valuable for original game development?
Why did you choose that specific 'late N64/early GameCube' graphical style? What does it allow you to do creatively?
How has the process of deconstructing and rebuilding SM64 shaped the core design philosophy for your own original game?

open_questions.context: Kaze described his philosophy on handling player feedback, which he calls the 'critic's dilemma,' where he focuses on the player's underlying feeling rather than their specific suggestion.
questions: Can you give a concrete example from this project where you received criticism, diagnosed the 'underlying feeling,' and implemented a different solution that successfully addressed it?
How does this philosophy change when the feedback comes from a core team member like Biobak or Badub, versus from the general community?
Do you ever find that the player's suggested solution is, in fact, the right one?

open_questions.context: The stream focused entirely on Kaze's work. While Zeina was mentioned in a personal context, the collaborative process with the artists (Biobak) and composer (Badub) was not discussed.
questions: Can you describe the typical workflow for a new enemy or level? At what point do you bring in Biobak for art or Badub for music?
